title: 109_hr4061
content: The Act may be cited as the "Department of Veterans Affairs Information Technology Management Improvement Act of 2005" and focuses on the management of information technology within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs Information Technology Management Improvement Act of 2005 amends Section 310 of title 38, United States Code to give the Chief Information Officer authority over IT objectives, policies, and plans. The Secretary must ensure the CIO has control over the development, approval, and oversight of IT policies and systems within the Department. The Chief Information Officer is responsible for developing and maintaining a process for selecting and overseeing information technology for the Department of Veterans Affairs. This includes creating an information technology strategic plan with performance measurements and an integrated enterprise architecture to support the Department's mission. The plan must be regularly reviewed and updated to align with technological changes and evolving mission needs. Funds for Department information technology must be allocated as specified by the Chief Information Officer and approved by the Secretary. Allocation methods for Veterans Health Administration funds must be consistent with the Veterans Equitable Resource allocation method. The Veterans Equitable Resource Allocation method requires approval from the Secretary and notification to the Under Secretary for Health. The Secretary must report requested amounts for information technology to Congress when the budget is submitted. The Chief Information Officer selects the CIO for each Administration within the Department. The Chief Information Officer selects CIOs for each Administration within the Department, who report to the Department Chief Information Officer and implement IT strategic plans. Each Department Deputy Chief Information Officer is responsible for maintaining operational control of information technology system assets and personnel for their respective Administrations. They advocate for the IT needs of their Administrations and ensure that business and mission requirements are met by coordinating with the Department Chief Information Officer. The Secretary is required to include details of approved obligations in the annual report. The report must assess the efficiency of information technology acquisition processes and management within the Department. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must provide progress reports to Congress on the implementation of certain sections of title 38, United States Code. The reports should include details on cost savings and accountability resulting from the provisions. The term 'information technology' is defined in section 11101 of title 40. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must provide progress reports to Congress on the implementation of certain sections of title 38, United States Code. The reports should include details on cost savings and accountability resulting from the provisions. Reports are required at the end of the 60-day, 90-day, and 180-day periods after enactment, with interim reports after 12 and 18 months. The reports will assess the increased efficiency within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a final report to Congress by January 1, 2008, on the implementation of provisions related to information technology management. The report should include details on cost savings, accountability, and recommendations for any modifications within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 2, 2005.
